description: Sir Christopher Wren's riverside masterpiece in Greenwich, built as the Royal Hospital for Seamen and begun in 1696.

factsheet.heading: Admiral’s House
paragraphs: Saturday 17 and Sunday 18 September, 10.00-17.00, drop-in.

One of the oldest surviving parts of the site, Admiral’s House, overlooking the Thames, was once the residence of the Governor of the Royal Hospital for Seamen. Originally designed by John Webb for Charles II as part of a plan to create a royal palace to rival Versailles. A rare chance to view this elegant space.
Access will be to the ground floor only.

factsheet.heading: Grand Square
paragraphs: Saturday 17, 10.30-12.30, and Sunday 18 September, 10.30-15.30, pop-up talks.
Bookable in-person, on the day.

The Grand Square of the Old Royal Naval College lies at the heart of one of the most spectacular architectural complexes in Europe.  These short talks will explore the histories behind the sweeping vistas on view.
The Grand Square talk will last approximately 15 minutes and will be repeated at half past the hour from 10.30 to 12.30 on 17 September and from 10.30 to 15.30 on 18 September.

factsheet.heading: King William Courtyard
paragraphs: Saturday 17 and Sunday 18 September, 11.00-16.00, pop-up talks.
Bookable in-person, on the day.

Hawksmoor’s work in the King William Courtyard, with its massive scale and sculptural enrichment, is a quintessential example of English Baroque architecture.  The Courtyard is overlooked by the Nelson Pediment, created in Coade stone to a design by the American-born history painter, Benjamin West. These short talks will explore the art and architecture of this unique space.
The King William Courtyard talk will last approximately 15 minutes and will be repeated on the hour from 11.00 to 16.00.
We regret there is no step-free access for this talk.

factsheet.heading: Jacobean Undercroft
paragraphs: Saturday 17 and Sunday 18 September, 11.00-16.00.
Bookable in-person, on the day.
A rare opportunity to visit the Undercroft of the Queen Anne Building, a survival from the early 1600s and the only remaining intact room from Greenwich Palace.
The Jacobean Undercroft visit will last approximately 20 minutes and will be repeated on the hour from 11.00 to 16.00.
The Undercroft is reached by a flight of steps: we regret there is no step-free access for this visit.

factsheet.heading: Chapel of St Peter and St Paul
paragraphs: Following the death of Her Majesty the Queen, the Chapel is open for quiet contemplation and prayer.
The Open House tours of the Chapel that were planned for 17 and 18 September have been cancelled.
A Choral Eucharist service will be held on Sunday 18 September at 11.00. All are welcome.

factsheet.heading: Visitor Centre
paragraphs: Every day, 10am - 5pm, drop-in.
The Visitor Centre features displays about the architecture of the site.

factsheet.heading: BSL Tours of the Jacobean Undercroft
paragraphs: Saturday 17 September, 11.30, 12.30
Advance booking necessary. Please visit ornc.org to book free tickets.
Discover more about the hidden history of the Jacobean Undercroft with a short talk by our BSL guide Alan Murray.
The Undercroft is reached by a flight of steps: we regret there is no step-free access for this visit.

factsheet.heading: BSL Tudor Site Tour
paragraphs: Saturday 17 September, 13.00
Advance booking necessary. Please visit ornc.org to book free tickets.
Join BSL tour guide, Alan Murray to find out about the layout of the site's former Tudor Palace buildings.
